text: Harold? Yeah, just a couple of comments.  And I referred back to the Papakāinga definition within our district plan. I recall that discussion when we first looked at creating an opportunity for Papakāinga. And what I do recall is that we were all quite naive around  what that actually meant, and hence the relationship to marae became the focus for the development of public haunga. But that seemed to be the institutional area on which those things were created for Māori at the time. That's 30 years ago now, and we're still trying to deal with it. But what I wanted to say that  The relationship with marae has no relevance whatsoever on Māori land or Māori-owned land in the district. And that's because of the many, what we call, negatives that have transpired around that ownership right. Things like Ropatu, the Māori Land Court,  the change from collective kaichake to individual ownership. Those are all negative impacts on how Māori see their relationship with their land and their whenua. And I think those are the more important things to focus on with respect to any change in our district plan regarding papakāinga. Because papakāinga is not about the institution,  as it was viewed at the time when we did the district plan back in 1990, 91, 92, whenever it was. Papakāinga are a right that Māori, mana whenua, are saying is theirs by right. Like any other person in New Zealand, the land that you own, you're allowed to build on. But Māori-owned land in this circumstance, we're not allowed to build on it.  We don't have the same rights as everyone else has, and these things have not been traversed until very recently. NKTR, for example, has been since 2018 trying to create a public hiring initiative for the Waiapae District Council and the other council areas adjacent to it.  And we've struggled against barrier after barrier ever since then, right up until today, and didn't very aware of those issues that we're trying to address. Even to the point where we're able to get a mitigation fund to allow that to happen, we still have not been able to draw down on that fund, some three or four years later. So these are,  what's called systemic issues that are inhibiting or obstructing our capacity to go and build houses for our people on our land. And I think that's the primary focus that any change for Papakāinga and the district should be. I see the reference to what they did in the Waikato district. Well, that was a far bet. They defaulted to the Māori Land Court  so that they didn't have to make the decisions, the hard decisions that I'm talking about right now. And I would expect WIPA, along with us, to sit down and find a way that we can do it together. And I'll give you an example of my confidence in WIPA to do this. When we attended and opposed the Waikete expansion in the Environment Court, I went there and I involved  the Waipa District Council is my ally to be able to provide for the mitigation of the impact of the Waikare build on affordable housing in the district. The difficulty in that was that our plan didn't allow us to be able to do the things we wanted to do with that money that was provided for that to happen. And today we're still sitting here trying to work out how the hell are we going to build some homes for our people?  It's now too late. The opportunity we had is gone. We've missed that opportunity because of these inadequacies that the district plan created, not only the district plan, the process itself created for our people to be able to be in affordable housing today. The only public hunger project that occurred within the Waipa District Council area was nothing more than  standard subdivision application. And that cost them over $80,000. Well, our people can't afford to do that every time they want to build a house on their lands. And we have, south of the Pune River, hundreds and hundreds of acres of Māori land. So in the small area that Waipae has south of the Pune River, we expect to use a lot of those lands  build houses for our people, but we can't. That is the problem with our district plan at the moment. So this public housing initiative is something that we've been working on for a while, and I'm really pleased that it's now come to the forefront. But as far as I'm concerned, we're not going to be copying what Waikato did, because it's totally inappropriate.  It's totally inappropriate because it does not recognize the ownership of individuals of their right to build on their land. And it defers to the Māori Land Court, which is nothing more than a process to ensure compliance with whatever it was that created it in the first place.  So I just wanted to put that on the table so that we can move forward with a focus, a clear focus on what public hauna actually means. And I think we can do it in Waipa because we've been along that pathway for quite some time and we didn't fully understand it, neither did I at the time. But I have a clearer picture now because the focus has been able to be put into effect by initiatives  that we created out of the Twin Kaukati Housing Network Initiative. So I just wanted to put that on the table, Mr. Mayor, for consideration of council and our people as well. Now, with respect to the Para Wairohui to announce this, I think the idea is good. But let's be very clear about this. You have up to five  separate iwi in your district. Each one is of its own authority. Each one is of its own customary requirements. Even though there are similarities within how they do things, each one has its own authority to do it in their own way. So bringing everyone together in a single place is not going to give you the answers.  It's not going to provide you with what you need to get down to the root cause and the root process of how we can do this right throughout your district. Waipā is probably one of the harder districts in the country to achieve all the initiatives for the separate Māori entities that are in there. You've got Waikato, you've got Ngāti Hauā, you've got Kahukura, you've got Raukawa, you've got Maniapoto, you've got Apakura,  And that's only the ones that I can read off the top of my head. So I think we need to be very cognizant of who we are dealing with within Waipā with respect to Papakāina. Because no two areas will be the same. We're not the same as how they did theirs in Waikato. The lands that we own here on south of the Punia were never ever taken away from us. The Waikato lands were confiscated and they were given back.  So there was nothing more than you can buy land now in Waikato and you can designate that Māori land. It's not quite the same thing as the ancestral land that is still in our retention. Now, we're not the only ones like that. There are other iwi tribal groups within Waikato that have that same status. So I'll just put that on the table as information for everyone to consider. Thank you, Mr. Mayor.

text: Good morning. It's just me on my own today, no Graham.  We've got in your agenda a report on the representation review 2021. We just launched the consultation on that on Friday. As you're aware, we adopted the Māori ward on the 19th of May, so that means a representation review is now compulsory. So as part of that review, we need to look at how many councillors we have, what areas they cover,  look at whether we want community boards or not, and also look at the Māori ward. So representation reviews are quite a process. We're just at the, in terms of the very start with our consultation with the community, we adopted an initial proposal, which is,  on the 17th of August at Finance and Corporate. And so that goes out to the community now for just over a month. The community have time to have input. We then have hearings. And then after those hearings, the council will adopt a final proposal. And then actually we go back out again. And then if anyone else has got any issues in terms of what council adopted as its final proposal,  then they can make an appeal or an objection and then the matter actually goes to the local government commission to decide. So we've done a few, there's a few changes that we have made with this representation review. So what we've done is we've actually, in terms of the councillor numbers, they have decreased. So we've gone down from 13 to 10 general ward councillors plus the Māori ward councillor.  We've looked at how our rural wards are structured. As part of the representational review, we've got to make sure that all the councillors represent kind of more or less the same amount of people. So we have some issues in terms of trying to juggle our urban and our rural wards.  because we have some of our urban wards like Cambridge that are growing at quite a rate. So what we've done there is we have looked at how we structure the rural wards. So we've ended up combining what was the Prongea Ward and the Kakapuku Rural Ward together into one ward. They're both areas that looked to Te Amuru as a service centre.  And then in terms of over the other side of the district, we've extended the Mangatauturi Ward around to include Kaipake. So there will be a number of people that will be in slightly different wards under this proposal. We have left the community boards in a very similar position to the community boards  what they are now, really the only change with them is that in the Cambridge subdivision, they dropped down from five to four. There are some minor changes that have been made to the urban wards to just accommodate where we think future growth might be happening as well.  So in terms of the Māori ward, the legislation sets out for us how many Māori ward members we can have and that really impacts on how, for us particularly,  in terms of our numbers, we're only eligible for one. And because we're only eligible for one under the calculation in the legislation, that means that it needs to be over the entire district. So we have, that's what we've had to go with. So really the only variable in terms of this representation review  in relation to the Māori ward is the name of that ward. So as staff, we worked with the strategic partnerships team to come up with a proposed name for the ward, and we took that through council as part of  the initial proposal when that was adopted and it is, you'll see in your paper there, the name that's been selected is Waipou Māori Ward. So really the purpose of today is to get any feedback that the committee might have on that and anything else that they wanna talk about in terms of the proposal that's in your agenda.  Has anyone got any comments? Thanks, Joe.
